description: The Content-Type header indicates the media type of the resource.

response-directives.description: Specifies the character encoding used in the response body.
response-directives.details: The charset directive is used to specify the character encoding used in the response body. If this directive is not present, the default encoding is usually ISO-8859-1. Common values include UTF-8 and UTF-16.

response-directives.description: Specifies the boundary string used for multipart entities.
response-directives.details: The boundary directive is used to specify the boundary string used for multipart entities. This is only used when the content-type is set to multipart/*.

response-directives.description: Specifies the media type of the resource.
response-directives.details: The type directive is used to specify the media type of the resource. This is typically in the format of a MIME type, such as text/html, image/png, or application/json.

response-directives.description: Specifies the natural language of the resource.
response-directives.details: The language directive is used to specify the natural language of the resource. This is typically in the format of a language tag, such as en-US or fr-CA. This can be used by user agents to automatically translate the content to the user's preferred language.

response-directives.description: Specifies the content transfer encoding of the resource.
response-directives.details: The encoding directive is used to specify the content transfer encoding of the resource. This is typically in the format of a content transfer encoding, such as base64 or quoted-printable.
